population_specificity: Rats (in vivo) and PC12 cells (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of ferulic acid (FA) in stabilizing mulberry anthocyanin extract (MAE) under thermal conditions at pH 6.3, both alone and in combination with whey protein isolate (WPI).
results_summary: Ferulic acid exhibited the best stabilizing effect among the copigments tested, reducing anthocyanin degradation significantly. The ternary system (MAE-WPI-FA) showed the highest stability, with a 38.0% reduction in degradation compared to the binary systems.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: To examine whether ferulic acid protects against ionizing radiation-induced lens injury in rats and to investigate the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Ferulic acid alleviated lens histological alterations, reduced oxidative damage, and inhibited apoptosis by modulating the Nrf2 signaling pathway, increasing antioxidant enzyme activities, and balancing apoptosis-related markers.
population_specificity: Rats exposed to ionizing radiation.
effective_dosage: 50 mg/kg administered for 4 days before and 3 days after radiation exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to comprehensively elucidate the mechanisms by which Ferulic Acid alleviates depression using animal models.
results_summary: Ferulic Acid significantly improved depressive-like behaviors in animal models through multiple mechanisms, including enhancing monoamine oxidase A activity, reducing inflammation, promoting hippocampal nerve regeneration, and regulating gut microbiome. The study suggests FA has potential as a natural treatment for depression.
population_specificity: Animal models (in vivo studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pharmacological effects, mechanisms, and therapeutic potential of Ferulic Acid (FA) in treating pulmonary diseases.
results_summary: FA demonstrated significant anti-oxidative and anti-inflammatory effects through various signaling pathways, showed potential in treating pulmonary fibrosis, asthma, and acute lung injury, and exhibited moderate neuraminidase inhibitory activity against influenza virus infections.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the antitumor effects and mechanisms of Ferulic Acid (FA), including its potential to inhibit cancer cell growth, induce apoptosis, and enhance chemotherapy efficacy.
results_summary: FA demonstrated anticancer activity by inducing mitochondrial apoptosis, interfering with the cancer cell cycle, inhibiting migration and angiogenesis, and enhancing chemotherapy effects. It targeted multiple signaling pathways, including PI3K/AKT, Bcl-2, and P53.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of preclinical and potential clinical mechanisms).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the bioaccessibility and cellular uptake of ferulic acid from muffins and bread made with hairless canary seed, wheat, and corn blends.
results_summary: Ferulic acid exhibited a wide range of bioaccessibility (53-229%) but very low cellular uptake (0.5-1.8%), suggesting limited absorption in the small intestine. Bread showed higher bioaccessibility (81-103%) compared to muffins, though uptake remained minimal.
population_specificity: In vitro (Caco-2 cell model) and simulated gastrointestinal digestion model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of ferulic acid and its derivatives on the oxidative stability of flaxseed oil and the degradation of bioactive compounds during oxidation.
results_summary: Ferulic acid and its derivatives improved the oxidative stability of flaxseed oil, with effectiveness varying by concentration and temperature. Some derivatives (DHFA and 4-VG) protected bioactive compounds, while VA increased their degradation.
population_specificity: Cold-pressed flaxseed oil (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of trans-ferulic acid (t-FA) on ram semen during liquid preservation, focusing on sperm kinematics, membrane functionality, viability, and biochemical parameters.
results_summary: The study found that 5 and 10 mM t-FA improved forward progressive motility and curvilinear velocity in ram spermatozoa after 72 hours, while 25 mM t-FA negatively impacted motility, viability, and antioxidant activity. Higher concentrations (25 mM) increased oxidative stress markers like malondialdehyde and reduced superoxide dismutase activity.
population_specificity: Qezel rams (specific breed of sheep)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of ferulic acid supplementation on lipid profiles, oxidative stress, and inflammatory status in individuals with hyperlipidemia.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that ferulic acid demonstrated anti-hyperlipidemic, anti-oxidative, and anti-inflammatory effects in vitro and animal studies, but human trial results are not fully detailed.
population_specificity: Subjects with hyperlipidemia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate an analytical method to quantify ferulic acid and other compounds in Prunus africana bark and pygeum products, comparing their concentrations.
results_summary: Ferulic acid was found predominantly in esterified form (>90%) in both bark and pygeum, with bark containing four times more total ferulic acid (450 μg/g) than pygeum. The study did not assess clinical outcomes but provided quantitative data on compound levels.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro analysis of plant material and commercial products).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Feru-guard 100M (containing ferulic acid and Angelica archangelica extract) could reduce amyloid beta deposition and improve cognitive function in individuals with mild cognitive impairment.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in amyloid beta deposition, brain atrophy, or cognitive function between the intervention and control groups after 48 weeks of supplementation. Feru-guard 100M did not reduce cortical PiB retention (reflecting Aβ deposition) or slow cognitive decline.
population_specificity: Seventeen subjects diagnosed with mild cognitive impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide a comprehensive review of the genus Cimicifuga, including its traditional uses, phytochemistry, pharmacological effects, and safety considerations, to inform future drug development.
results_summary: The study identified over 457 compounds in Cimicifuga, with triterpene glycosides as the primary bioactive constituents. Pharmacological research validated traditional uses, showing benefits for menopausal symptoms, osteoporosis, and antiviral/antitumor effects, but also reported toxicity risks in liver, cardiovascular, and nervous systems.
population_specificity: Not specified (broad ethnopharmacological review).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antibacterial activity of ferulic acid against Cronobacter sakazakii strains and elucidate its potential mechanisms of action.
results_summary: Ferulic acid showed moderate antimicrobial activity against C. sakazakii, with minimum inhibitory concentrations ranging from 2.5 to 5.0 mg/mL. It disrupted bacterial membrane integrity, reduced intracellular ATP, altered pH, and caused hyperpolarization, leading to inhibited proliferation and morphological damage.
population_specificity: Cronobacter sakazakii strains (in vitro study).
study_duration: Immediate and sustained effects observed (specific duration not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Ferulic Acid's potential role in inducing apoptosis and inhibiting colon cancer induced by CT26 cell transplantation.
results_summary: FA adjuvant treatment upregulated autophagy-related genes, suppressed inflammatory response elements, improved bodyweight and liver enzyme levels (ALT, AST), and inhibited CT26 cell proliferation by activating ERK and JNK phosphorylation to enhance apoptosis-related proteins (BCL-2, BAX).
population_specificity: In vivo study (specific organism not stated, likely animal model based on CT26 cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential applications of Ferulic Acid, as a component of Polypodium leucotomos extract, in dermatology and immunomodulation, focusing on its antioxidant and photoprotective effects.
results_summary: The study found that Ferulic Acid, as part of Polypodium leucotomos extract, exhibits antioxidant activity, controls ultraviolet-induced erythema, intercepts inflammatory mechanisms, and improves cell membrane integrity and elastin expression. It also showed potential in delaying tumor development in mice models, though human clinical data on carcinogenesis prevention is lacking.
population_specificity: Mice models and inferred human applications (no specific human population detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the bioactive effects of phenolic compounds in Brewers' spent grain (BSG), including ferulic acid, focusing on antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, anti-atherogenic, and anti-cancer properties.
results_summary: The study found that ferulic acid and other hydroxycinnamic acids in BSG exhibit antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, anti-atherogenic, and anti-cancer effects. BSG phenolic extracts also showed potential in protecting against oxidant-induced DNA damage, possibly through Fe chelation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing evidence, not a specific clinical or experimental population).

study_goal: To investigate the efficacy and safety of a fixed combination supplement including Feverfew for episodic migraine prevention.
results_summary: The supplement significantly reduced monthly migraine days, headache intensity, and acute medication use, with 56.6% of patients achieving ≥50% reduction in migraine days. No safety concerns were reported.
population_specificity: 113 Greek patients with episodic migraine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an HPTLC method for quantifying bioactive compounds in feverfew and comparing its antioxidant activity with German chamomile and marigold.
results_summary: Feverfew leaf extracts contained parthenolide, but chamazulene and bisabolol were more concentrated in chamomile and calendula. Chamomile extracts showed the highest antioxidant activity, with bisabolol and chamazulene being the most effective antioxidants.
population_specificity: Not specified (plant extracts analyzed in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the chemical and biological properties of three Danggui Buxue Tang (DBT) formulations, including the presence and effects of Ferulic Acid derived from Angelicae Sinensis Radix (ASR).
results_summary: The DBT formulation from 1247 AD contained the highest levels of Ferulic Acid and demonstrated stronger osteogenic, estrogenic, and erythropoietic effects compared to the other two formulations. The study supports the historical preference for this specific DBT formulation due to its superior biological activity.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or animal models based on abstract).

study_goal: To explore the effect and mechanism of feverfew lactone on inducing autophagic death of hepatocellular carcinoma SMMC 7721 cells.
results_summary: Feverfew lactone inhibited the proliferation of SMMC 7721 cells in a concentration-dependent manner and induced autophagy, as evidenced by increased LC3 expression and autophagic flow, and decreased p62. The effect was mediated by ROS production, as antioxidant NAC reduced autophagy.
population_specificity: Hepatocellular carcinoma SMMC 7721 cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antihyperalgesic properties of feverfew in streptozotocin-diabetic rats to assess its potential as a treatment for painful diabetic peripheral neuropathy.
results_summary: A feverfew flower extract partially relieved neuropathic pain, while a feverfew leaf extract was ineffective. The efficacy of feverfew appeared to be linked to the presence of parthenolide, and no behavioral side effects or altered locomotor activity were observed.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-diabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of a purified parthenolide-depleted Feverfew (PD-Feverfew) extract on the ARE-Nrf2 pathway and DNA repair in skin cells.
results_summary: PD-Feverfew induced Nrf2 nuclear translocation and increased ARE activity dose-dependently, reduced UV-induced DNA damage in a PI3K and Nrf2-dependent manner, and activated a PI3K-dependent Nrf2/ARE pathway.
population_specificity: Primary human keratinocytes or KB cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compile and synthesize existing knowledge on Feverfew's pharmacologic properties and therapeutic applications.
results_summary: The study highlights Feverfew's diverse traditional uses and pharmacologic properties, including anticancer, anti-inflammatory, and antispasmodic effects, supported by its active constituents like parthenolide. The plant's importance as a multipurpose medicinal agent is growing with increasing evidence of its therapeutic benefits.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of traditional and folk medicine uses)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antimigraine mechanism of feverfew supercritical extract by examining its effects on nitric oxide and TNF-α production in mouse macrophage cells.
results_summary: Feverfew extract inhibited nitric oxide and TNF-α production in a dose-dependent manner, with complete NO inhibition at 5 µg/mL. It down-regulated eNOS and iNOS proteins without affecting their mRNA levels, suggesting post-translational regulation.
population_specificity: Mouse macrophage cell line (RAW 264.7)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the timing and localization of parthenolide biosynthesis in Feverfew and isolate genes involved in its production.
results_summary: The study found that glandular trichomes are the primary sites of parthenolide biosynthesis and accumulation, with the highest expression of germacrene A synthase (TpGAS) observed in these tissues and during active flower development stages.
population_specificity: Not specified (plant tissues and developmental stages analyzed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of sublingual feverfew/ginger as an abortive treatment for migraine attacks, particularly when administered early during the mild headache phase.
results_summary: The study found that feverfew/ginger was significantly more effective than placebo in achieving pain-free status (32% vs. 16%) and pain relief (63% vs. 39%) at 2 hours. It was generally well tolerated, with oral numbness and nausea being the most common adverse events.
population_specificity: Migraineurs experiencing 2-6 attacks per month, able to identify mild headache phases in at least 75% of attacks, and not suffering from medication overuse headache.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether parthenolide, a compound derived from Feverfew, could stimulate platelet production and reduce undesirable platelet activation.
results_summary: Parthenolide stimulated functional platelet production in human and mouse megakaryocytes by inhibiting nuclear factor-κB signaling and independently of oxidative stress. It also attenuated activation in stimulated human platelets.
population_specificity: Human megakaryoblastic cell lines, primary human and mouse megakaryocytes, and human peripheral blood platelets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review randomized controlled trials to assess the clinical findings and implications of Feverfew for migraine prophylaxis.
results_summary: The study suggests Feverfew may benefit certain subsets of migraine patients, though data pooling was not feasible. Long-term dosing raises potential concerns due to cyclooxygenase-2 inhibition, particularly for coronary disease patients.
population_specificity: Migraine patients (specific subsets not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the cellular targets and gene expression profiles affected by feverfew extracts in human monocytic THP-1 cells to understand its mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The study identified 400 genes regulated by feverfew extracts, primarily involved in cellular metabolism, chemokine function, water homeostasis, and heme-mediated signaling. Feverfew extracts also reduced LPS-mediated TNF-alpha and CCL2 (MCP-1) releases in THP-1 cells, suggesting effects on metabolism, cell migration, and cytokine production.
population_specificity: Human monocytic THP-1 cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a parthenolide-depleted extract of Feverfew (PD-Feverfew) could protect skin from environmental damage by scavenging free radicals, reducing inflammation, and promoting DNA repair.
results_summary: PD-Feverfew demonstrated strong free radical scavenging activity, restored cellular thiols, reduced UV-induced damage, and significantly decreased erythema post-UV exposure compared to placebo. It also attenuated pro-inflammatory cytokine release and DNA damage.
population_specificity: Human subjects (clinical study) and in vitro models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the anticancer effects of parthenolide, an active component of feverfew, in melanoma cells in vitro.
results_summary: Parthenolide reduced viable melanoma cells, with half maximal inhibitory concentration values around 4 μmol/l, inducing cell death via mitochondrial membrane depolarization and caspase-3 activation. Metastatic melanoma cells were more susceptible to parthenolide than vertical growth phase melanoma cells or melanocytes at concentrations ≥6 μmol/l.
population_specificity: Melanoma cell lines, melanocytes, and melanoma cells derived from surgical excision.
interactions: Interaction with intracellular thiols (e.g., N-acetyl-cysteine) noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the potential reproductive toxicity of Feverfew in pregnant rats, focusing on maternal and fetal outcomes.
results_summary: Feverfew exposure reduced maternal weight gain (attributed to litter size), increased pre-implantation loss (non-significant), and resulted in smaller fetuses with more runts in the GD8-15 group. In vitro, Feverfew induced toxicity in cultured embryos.
population_specificity: Pregnant female rats (in vivo) and GD10.5 rat embryos (in vitro).
study_duration: Gestation days 1-8 or 8-15 (in vivo); 26 hours (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of parthenolide, derived from Feverfew, to selectively induce apoptosis in AML stem cells while sparing normal blood cells.
results_summary: The study found that parthenolide preferentially induced apoptosis in AML stem cells without affecting normal blood cells, suggesting its potential as a targeted therapy for leukemia.
population_specificity: Acute myelogenous leukaemia (AML) stem cells and normal blood cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the inhibitory activity of parthenolide and golden feverfew extract against human breast and cervical cancer cell lines, as well as potential synergistic effects with flavonoids.
results_summary: Feverfew ethanolic extract inhibited the growth of three cancer cell lines (Hs605T, MCF-7, SiHa), with parthenolide showing the highest inhibitory effect. Apigenin and luteolin exhibited moderate to weak synergistic effects with parthenolide.
population_specificity: Human breast (Hs605T, MCF-7) and cervical (SiHa) cancer cell lines.
effective_dosage: EC50 values: 1.5 mg/mL (Hs605T), 2.1 mg/mL (MCF-7), 0.6 mg/mL (SiHa) for feverfew extract; 2.6–2.8 µg/mL for parthenolide.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of GelStat Migraine (a combination of feverfew and ginger) as an early abortive treatment for migraines when taken during the mild pain phase.
results_summary: 48% of subjects were pain-free two hours after treatment, and 34% reported only mild headache severity. Side effects were minimal, and 59% of subjects were satisfied with the therapy.
population_specificity: 30 subjects (male and female) with a one-year history of migraines (2-8 per month) that consistently started mild and worsened if untreated.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of a CO(2)-extract of feverfew (MIG-99) for migraine prevention compared to placebo.
results_summary: MIG-99 reduced migraine frequency by 1.9 attacks per month compared to 1.3 with placebo, showing statistical significance (P = 0.0456). Adverse events were similar between groups (8.4% for MIG-99 vs. 10.2% for placebo), indicating a favorable benefit-risk ratio.
population_specificity: Patients suffering from migraine according to International Headache Society criteria (N = 170 intention-to-treat).
study_duration: 16 weeks of treatment after a 4-week baseline period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the molecular mechanisms behind parthenolide's anti-inflammatory activity in Feverfew.
results_summary: The study found that parthenolide binds to and inhibits IKKbeta, a kinase critical in cytokine-mediated signaling, and that its anti-inflammatory effects are mediated through the alpha-methylene gamma-lactone moiety.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo study, no human population mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Feverfew in migraine prophylaxis as an additive treatment.
results_summary: The study observed a significant reduction in Migraine Index in 8 out of 24 patients and a less significant reduction in 5 additional patients, suggesting Feverfew may be beneficial for migraine prophylaxis.
population_specificity: 24 female patients aged 19-61 years with migraine.
effective_dosage: 5 ml of sap administered once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical effectiveness of feverfew in preventing migraines through a systematic review of randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind trials.
results_summary: Five trials met the inclusion criteria, with the majority favoring feverfew over placebo, though the clinical effectiveness was not conclusively established. Important caveats were noted regarding the evidence.
population_specificity: Not specified (general migraine prevention population implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the dose-response relationship, safety, and tolerability of a new stable feverfew extract (MIG-99) for migraine prophylaxis.
results_summary: MIG-99 did not show a significant prophylactic effect in the general migraine population but demonstrated a dose-dependent reduction in migraine attacks in a predefined subgroup with frequent baseline attacks (≥4 attacks in 28 days). Safety profiles were similar across all treatment groups, with no dose-related adverse effects.
population_specificity: Patients with migraine (with or without aura) according to IHS criteria (n = 147).
effective_dosage: 2.08 mg, 6.25 mg, and 18.75 mg three times daily (t.i.d.).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral feverfew is effective in treating rheumatoid arthritis symptoms compared to a placebo.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in clinical or laboratory variables between the feverfew and placebo groups, indicating no apparent benefit from feverfew in rheumatoid arthritis.
population_specificity: 41 female patients with symptomatic rheumatoid arthritis.
effective_dosage: 70-86 mg dried chopped feverfew once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of feverfew for migraine prophylaxis in a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled crossover study.
results_summary: Feverfew treatment reduced the mean number and severity of migraine attacks and decreased vomiting, with no change in attack duration. Visual analogue scores showed significant improvement, and no serious side-effects were reported.
population_specificity: 72 volunteers (60 completed the study) with migraines.
effective_dosage: One capsule of dried feverfew leaves daily.
study_duration: Four months per treatment limb (total eight months including crossover).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the feasibility of short-segment cement-augmented carbon fiber-reinforced polyetheretherketone (CFRP) instrumentation for patients with spinal metastasis requiring separation surgery.
results_summary: The study found that short-segment cement-augmented CFRP instrumentation was feasible, with no cement- or hardware-related complications, and a mean survival of 14.9 months. Postoperative complications were minimal and manageable nonoperatively.
population_specificity: Patients with metastatic epidural spinal cord compressions (MESCCs) requiring separation surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a proprietary supplement containing Feverfew, coenzyme Q10, and magnesium for migraine prophylaxis in adult patients.
results_summary: The supplement significantly reduced the number of migraine days, with a progressive decrease over three months, and improved quality of life while being well tolerated. A high proportion of patients (75%) achieved at least a 50% reduction in migraine days by the third month.
population_specificity: Adult patients with migraine (≥2 attacks in the previous month), excluding chronic migraine and medication overuse.
effective_dosage: 100 mg Feverfew, 100 mg coenzyme Q10, and 112.5 mg magnesium per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether feverfew capsules (containing 0.5 mg parthenolide) were effective for migraine prophylaxis in patients who had not previously used feverfew.
results_summary: The study found no prophylactic effect of feverfew on migraine attacks compared to placebo, though patients tended to use fewer symptomatic drugs during feverfew treatment. These results contradicted prior studies, possibly due to differences in patient selection (prior positive experiences with feverfew).
population_specificity: 50 patients with migraines, none of whom had used feverfew before.
effective_dosage: 0.5 mg parthenolide per capsule, taken once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Feverfew, when taken prophylactically, prevents migraine attacks in patients who previously self-treated with the herb.
results_summary: The placebo group experienced a significant increase in migraine frequency and severity, while the Feverfew group showed no change in symptoms, suggesting Feverfew may prevent migraine attacks. Confirmatory studies with standardized formulations are recommended.
population_specificity: Seventeen patients who previously ate fresh Feverfew leaves daily for migraine prophylaxis.
effective_dosage: Freeze-dried Feverfew powder (exact dosage not specified).
study_duration: Early months of treatment (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term durability and stability of CFR-PEEK constructs in patients with metastatic spine disease and assess the necessity of cement augmentation in short-segment constructs.
results_summary: CFR-PEEK instrumentation showed excellent durability and stability with no radiographic failures or revision surgeries observed. Short-segment constructs demonstrated comparable durability to long-segment ones without routine cement augmentation, though cement use was linked to longer hospital stays.
population_specificity: Patients with metastatic spine disease undergoing surgical fixation with CFR-PEEK hardware, stratified into short-construct (n = 13) and long-construct (n = 7) groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the durability and failure rates of CFR-PEEK instrumentation in patients with spine tumors over long-term follow-up.
results_summary: The study found a 4.1% rate of mechanical/hardware failure in CFR-PEEK instrumentation, with no failures observed in patients with over 24-month follow-up, suggesting comparable durability to titanium implants.
population_specificity: Patients with spine tumors who underwent instrumented spinal fusion (age >18 years, minimum 6-month follow-up).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surgical instrumentation, not a supplement).
study_duration: Median follow-up of 13.7 months (range up to >24 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review consensus documents and literature to determine the indications, benefits, and precautions of using dietary fiber in treating pediatric dyslipidemia.
results_summary: The study found that dietary fiber is beneficial for improving lipid profiles and reducing cardiovascular risk in children and adolescents with dyslipidemia, though specific precautions are advised.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with dyslipidemia, including conditions like Familial Hypercholesterolemia and obesity-related dyslipidemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the generation, characterization, and pulmonary toxicities of ferrocene-derived magnetic particles (FMP) in diesel exhaust, as well as their associated mechanisms in an avian model.
results_summary: FMP was found to be fibrous, magnetic iron-containing carbon particles that induced pulmonary toxicity in hatchling chickens. The study identified ferroptosis via Bach1, SAT1, and polyamines depletion as the underlying molecular mechanism.
population_specificity: Hatchling chickens (avian model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a cell-free enzyme pretreatment combined with cationic starch in improving dewatering efficiency and paper strength in bleached hardwood pulp fibers, while assessing environmental and economic impacts.
results_summary: The treatment increased solids by 11%, improved tensile strength by 25%, reduced water retention value by 27%, and lowered global warming potential by 12%, yielding net savings of $11.29 per air-dried ton of paper.
population_specificity: Bleached hardwood pulp fibers (industrial application, not human consumption).
effective_dosage: Not specified (enzyme cocktail and cationic starch combination used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the clinical and imaging features of central bouquet hemorrhage (CBH) with Henle fiber layer (HFL) involvement in highly myopic eyes and investigate its relationship with visual outcomes and reabsorption time.
results_summary: The study found that CBH with HFL involvement in highly myopic eyes improved visual acuity from baseline, with hemorrhage clearing after a mean of 2.63 months. Structural alterations persisted post-resolution, and anti-VEGF treatment did not significantly affect outcomes.
population_specificity: Highly myopic eyes (mean refractive error -14.8 ± 3.14 diopters) with CBH involving HFL.
study_duration: Mean hemorrhage clearance time was 2.63 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of corn leaf fiber, enhanced with kaolinite clay and calcium carbonate, for reducing dissolved phosphorus in agricultural tile drain systems.
results_summary: Corn leaf fiber alone reduced phosphate concentration by 8.75%, but when enhanced with 30% kaolinite clay and 35% calcium carbonate, phosphate reduction improved to 79.40%. The study confirmed phosphorus presence in the enhanced adsorbent material post-treatment.
population_specificity: Agricultural tile drain systems (not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: 30% w/w kaolinite clay and 35% w/w calcium carbonate incorporated into corn leaf fiber.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding layered carbon fiber (CF) reinforcement to polycarbonate (PC) and applying homogeneous electron beam irradiation (HLEBI) could improve impact strength and bending strength.
results_summary: Adding cross-weave CF layers to PC significantly increased impact strength, with a 216 kGy HLEBI dose proving optimal for enhancing both impact and bending strength. Higher doses (432 kGy) improved adhesion but degraded PC resin, reducing impact strength.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study, no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: 43.2, 129, 216, 302, or 432 kGy HLEBI at 170 kV acceleration voltage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of cellulase-xylanase synergistic treatment combined with twin-screw extrusion on the physicochemical, functional, and in vitro fermentation characteristics of buckwheat bran dietary fiber (BBDF).
results_summary: The synergetic modification significantly increased the soluble dietary fiber (SDF) ratio, improved functional properties and prebiotic activities, and enhanced glucose and cholesterol adsorption capacities. Enzymatically extruded BBDF also showed higher short-chain fatty acid (SCFA) yields during in vitro fecal fermentation, with notably increased butyrate production.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).
effective_dosage: 0.6% (w/w) cellulase and xylanase under mild extrusion conditions (40-80 °C).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a bioinspired, nanoporous metal-organic framework-modified basalt fiber fabric (BFF) for efficient and sustainable oil-water separation.
results_summary: The study found that the composite membrane demonstrated superior oil-water separation performance, with excellent flux and oil rejection rates, as well as exceptional stability and reusability. The bioinspired design enhanced hydrophilicity and underwater superoleophobicity, making it effective for environmental applications.
population_specificity: Not applicable (environmental application, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of natural organic matter (NOM) and dissolved solids on fluoride retention in polyelectrolyte multilayer-based hollow-fiber nanofiltration membranes (dNF40).
results_summary: The dNF40 membranes showed fluoride retention above 70% without NOM and competing ions, but retention dropped to ~60% in synthetic model water (SMW) and further declined to ~20% due to fouling effects. Monovalent anion retention decreased significantly, especially at higher recovery rates, while divalent cation retention improved.
population_specificity: Not applicable (lab-scale filtration experiments, no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (operating conditions varied, but no dosage specified).
study_duration: Not specified (batch filtration experiments conducted, but duration not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate microplastic fiber (MPF) release during chemical recycling of polyester/cotton-blended textiles using acid and alkaline hydrolysis methods.
results_summary: Dye removal generated the highest MPF count (10,055 MPFs g-1). Alkaline hydrolysis reduced MPF release by 87.55% compared to acid hydrolysis, indicating PET degradation minimizes MPF emissions. Reaction conditions and blend ratios influenced MPF fragmentation.
population_specificity: Post-consumer polyester/cotton-blended textiles.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of surface carbonization of stalk fibers on the mechanical and thermal properties of alkali-activated cement-based composites.
results_summary: Surface carbonization improved mechanical properties and thermal insulation performance of the composites, outperforming NaOH immersion treatment, with a thermal conductivity coefficient of 0.2373 W/m²·K. A machine learning framework was also developed to predict material performance based on modified stalk microstructure.
population_specificity: Not specified (material science study, not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report an atypical presentation of ocular toxoplasmosis involving Henle fiber layer (HFL) hemorrhages and its diagnosis using multimodal imaging.
results_summary: The study found that HFL hemorrhages are a novel finding in ocular toxoplasmosis, with the patient responding well to medical treatment. Multimodal imaging, including OCT, was effective for diagnosis and monitoring.
population_specificity: A 56-year-old HIV-positive female from southeast Brazil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of a 1070 nm Ytterbium Fiber Laser (YFL) versus hydrofluoric acid on the shear bond strength of lithium disilicate ceramics to enamel.
results_summary: The study found that shear bond strengths were comparable between YFL and hydrofluoric acid treatments, with no significant effect from sample thickness or surface treatment. SEM analysis showed micro-roughness in acid-treated samples and mini-laser spots in laser-treated groups, with no microfractures or cracks detected.
population_specificity: Bovine teeth (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: 20 W average power YFL for laser treatment; 4.5% hydrofluoric acid for 20 s for acid treatment

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of ginger intake on weight loss, glycemic control, and lipid profiles in overweight and obese subjects.
results_summary: The study pooled data from randomized controlled trials and used standardized mean differences to assess ginger's effects, but specific outcome details are not provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight potential herb-drug interactions involving ginger and other popular herbs used by cancer patients.
results_summary: The abstract mentions ginger as one of the herbs commonly used by cancer patients but does not provide specific results regarding its effects. It emphasizes the potential for interactions with standard drugs, including chemotherapy.
population_specificity: Cancer patients using herbal supplements alongside standard treatments.
interactions: Potential interactions with prescription medications, including chemotherapy drugs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of ginger supplementation on ADMA and ICAM-1 serum levels in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: Ginger supplementation significantly decreased ADMA serum levels and marginally reduced sICAM-1 levels in the intervention group, though the between-group differences were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 45 patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (23 in the ginger group, 22 in the placebo group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ginger root supplementation reduces muscle soreness and dysfunction caused by downhill running.
results_summary: The study found that ginger root likely reduced the increase in muscle soreness after downhill running compared to placebo, as measured by jogging soreness post-run. Other outcomes (pain-pressure threshold, vertical jump, and 1.5-mile run performance) were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 32 runners (10 women, 22 men) engaged in distance running.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the effect of ginger supplementation on lipid parameters, specifically triacylglycerol (TAG), low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C), total cholesterol (TC), and high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C).
results_summary: Ginger supplementation significantly reduced TAG and LDL-C levels but had no significant effect on TC or HDL-C. Lower doses (≤2 g/day) showed greater reductions in TAG and TC compared to higher doses (>2 g/day).
population_specificity: Adult participants with elevated blood lipids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of KaempMax™, an ethanol extract of Kaempferia parviflora (a ginger family plant), on erectile function in healthy middle-aged and older men.
results_summary: Supplementation with KaempMax™ resulted in statistically significant improvements in erectile function, intercourse satisfaction, and total IIEF scores. The supplement was well tolerated with an excellent safety profile, though effects were less pronounced than prescription medications.
population_specificity: Generally healthy males aged 50-68 years with self-reported mild erectile dysfunction, not using prescription treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate and compare the inhibitory effects of ginger phytochemicals (6-, 8-, and 10-gingerols/shogaols) on canonical NLRP3 inflammasome-mediated IL-1β secretion in THP-1 macrophages.
results_summary: At 20 μM, 10-gingerol and all shogaols significantly inhibited IL-1β secretion, with shogaols showing greater potency than corresponding gingerols. These phytochemicals also reduced pro-IL-1β, NLRP3 expression, and caspase-1 activation, with 6-shogaol being the most effective.
population_specificity: THP-1 macrophages (in vitro study)
